entry.title: Changing Timezone on Heroku
entry.content:
Howdy! I know you're here because you're a Heroku fan or a forced Heroku user.

Well, it's not a big deal though.

Honestly, I really like how you can wrap up things quickly via Heroku. Heroku's automation is way bitcher than bitch. I'm a fan, YES! But it's not that I can always afford their sky-high packages.

So much about it, I'll shut my mouth now before a Heroku spy learns everything about me. I want to live longer, you know.

What is a timezone?




Timezone, is a region that has a uniform standard time for legal, commercial, and social purposes. It is convenient for areas in close commercial or other communication to keep the same time, so time zones tend to follow the boundaries of countries and their subdivisions.

By the way, thanks to Wikipedia, for the oh-so-meaningful meaning of Timezone.

What do you need before changing timezone on Heroku Cedar stack?

Appropriate Timezone Name String? That sounds weird?

First, you really need to know your desired appropriate zone name string.

Search for your desired zone name string here.

Second, open your console/shell so that you could perform the command needed in changing the timezone.

Example, my zone name string is America/Vancouver

Simply run this command:

heroku config:add TZ=America/Vancouver

Your Heroku app will restart after!



Oh well, you can check/test if it's really working by performing the ff:

In console/shell, run: 

heroku run console

Then, check the time:

Time.now



That should be all set for you!

entry.title: Setting up your default local web server in Mountain Lion

link.title: Setting up your default local web server in Mountain Lion

entry.content:
By default, there is a local web server nailed in your MAC!

Before, you can enable it via System Preferences > Sharing > Web Sharing

But, things are already different since Mountain Lion. OS X Mountain Lion does not include Web Sharing as an option in the Sharing preference pane. Mountain Lion does include the Apache HTTP Server, an open-source web server (ref: Apple Discussions Forum).

How to activate Apache HTTP Server in OSX Mountain Lion?




First, you need to create a .conf file in your /etc/apache2/users/ folder.

Run this command to create your own: 

sudo pico /etc/apache2/users/username.conf

Remember that username is the short name of your user account:

Naturally, the file will be opened in a VIM text editor.

Copy the following sample configuration file into your own .conf file. Replace the /Users/xiruki/Sites/ path by your own path.

Make sure that you already have an existing Sites folder inside your /Users/username folder

Save and Exit!

Open your terminal and start your local web server:

sudo apachectl start

If you didn't encounter any errors upon starting the server, then you may now run other apachectl commands!

  • sudo apachectl stop
  • sudo apachectl restart

Lastly, you may now access your http://localhost.
This is the default content of your localhost:

To access your Sites folder, go to http://localhost/~username/


Now you have your local web server running! Congratulations!

entry.title: Installing Phonegap in MAC OSX
entry.content:
Start creating awesome mobile applications using this technology!

Phonegap is an open source framework for quickly building cross-platform mobile apps using HTML5, Javascript and CSS. It supports various platforms such as...

  • IOS
  • Android
  • Blackberry OS
  • WebOS
  • Windows
  • Symbian
  • Bada</a> </ul> </p>

    How to install Phonegap in MAC OSX?




    First, you need to install Node JS and NPM (Node Package Modules). We can achieve those via Homebrew, the missing package manager for OS X.

    Install Homebrew via this command: 

    ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"

    After installing Homebrew, follow the generated instructions!

    Make sure that once you run the `brew doctor` command, everything is fine and no warnings are executed.

    Once Homebrew is setup correctly, it's time to install Node JS via brew!

    brew install node

    Then, install NPM...

    curl https://npmjs.org/install.sh | sh

    Finally, it's time for you to install Phonegap all the way!

    sudo npm install -g phonegap

    For more info: Check it here!


    I'll be posting a sample tutorial on how to use Phonegap soon! So wait for it!

entry.title: First encounter with RAILS
entry.content:
So given that you came from a lot of other programming languages
and frameworks...

PHP, ASP.net, Java, C#, Perl, VB, Lua, Python, etc..
And you want to apprise yourself that RUBY has its own frameworks too.

  • Padrino
  • Ramaze
  • Sinatra
  • Fiasco
  • Merb
  • Rails
  • and more... </ul> </p>

    RAILS? Can I eat that?




    I wouldn't say that Rails is the best of the best. But I might say that Rails is in the mainstream apart from other Ruby frameworks.

    First, you might say that it will be hard for you to accept it from soup to nuts because it looks really weird and unpopular unlike PHP and other stuffs.

    But, the thing is that... You will surely love its unique structure and marvelous concept.

    Second, you don't need to force yourself to learn everything quickly! Of course, it would not be so easy if it's just your first time to use an MVC framework.

    Third, if you already have an experience in MVC frameworks just like ZEND for PHP, Django for Python, ASP.net MVC for .net, Seaside for Smalltalk, Catalyst for Perl, Wicket for Java and other frameworks... then it would be easy for you to accept RAILS. I'm sure about that.




    Thousands of companies (from startup to giant) are already using RAILS for their applications.

    • Github
    • Basecamp
    • Twitter
    • Groupon
    • Shopify
    • Yellowpages
    • and a lot more...</a> </ul> </p>

      That is it! You can now say that Ruby on Rails is a promising Ruby framework.

      What do I need to make it possible?

      References were baked in as well! If you want to start learning RAILS immediately... then you need the following steps (randomly):

      • Start lurking around the official site to get an overview about RAILS! This site should be one of your official homes. Of course, you still need a real home. Lol. And we all know that we cannot live virtually forever. RAILS has a nice blog for recent news and announcements too. You have to be updated too. Also, the RAILS people are generous enough to deliver a good set of guidelines and "Getting Started" articles for the community. Please see the official Guide book and detailed documentation.

      • Read EBOOKS such as Beginning Rails 3, Rails in Action, Jump Start Rails, and some other books by Pragmatic Bookshelf. Ebooks are complete and very detailed. So, if you want to gain a lot of information and you are into reading books then this step might be just for you.

      • I would also like to recommend the most popular Rails tutorial by Michael Hartl. Go here and be amazed!

      • If you are used to learn via Screencasts and/or video tutorials, then Railscasts and Peepcode would be suitable for you.

      • Did you know that you can also learn RAILS interactively? Online courses in a bright and fun way would be so nice to try! Learn a lot of stuffs from Code School. They have an awesome kick named Rails for Zombies that you would possibly enjoy! Websites that are related with Code School are... Code Learn, Code Academy etc..

      • Gems are plugins-like that would be helpful for your starter apps. See the official RubyGems site for more info. Related stuffs: Ruby Toolbox, Gemnasium, Gemcanary and more more more.

      • If you get stuck and you need some help... Don't hesitate to ask for a hand. You could ask some RAILS related questions in Stack Overflow, and/or straight from the Rails community. Forum? Visit Rails Forum for more connections.

      • Bloggers also exist to give us more knowledge about Rails. Ruby Flow and Planet Ruby on Rails are some of the good examples.

      • Before anything else, please make sure that you already have a working Rails environment in your machine! Read installation instructions from this post or this post. I'll be posting my own version soon!

      • Also, Github is a place where you can see a lot of working sample applications using RAILS. Recent details about various working gems are also posted there. I'll be also posting a post to what Git is all about!

      A sense of patience, fun and hardwork

      It is clear that "Nothing is easy for the first time". It's not as easy as pie. There's nothing like the first time, so you have to be more patient and hardworking. Learning is fun and it never stops. In this Rails Forum post, I posted a little bit about my first impression with RAILS. Hope you will learn something from there.
